title: Add Google Analytics tracking to sign in pages
description:
## Overview
The goal of this issue is to add Google Analytics tracking to all SaaS sign-up and sign-in pages. This will allow the marketing team to get further insight into which campaigns are successful in driving sign-ups and trials. 
 
This work has been approved by legal [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/7812#note_357576259).
 
## Implementation

Add the tracking code below to the identified pages. 
 
Paste this code as high in the `<head>` of the page as possible:
```
<!-- Google Tag Manager -->
<script>(function(w,d,s,l,i){w[l]=w[l]||[];w[l].push({'gtm.start':
new Date().getTime(),event:'gtm.js'});var f=d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
j=d.createElement(s),dl=l!='dataLayer'?'&l='+l:'';j.async=true;j.src=
'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id='+i+dl;f.parentNode.insertBefore(j,f);
})(window,document,'script','dataLayer','GTM-NJXWQL');</script>
<!-- End Google Tag Manager -->
```
Additionally, paste this code immediately after the opening `<body>` tag:
```
<!-- Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->
<noscript><iframe src="https://www.googletagmanager.com/ns.html?id=GTM-NJXWQL"
height="0" width="0" style="display:none;visibility:hidden"></iframe></noscript>
<!-- End Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->
```
 
Pages we need to add this tracking to: 
* https://gitlab.com/-/trials/new
* https://gitlab.com/-/trial_registrations/new
* https://gitlab.com/-/trials/select
* https://gitlab.com/users/sign_in
* https://gitlab.com/users/sign_up

title: Technical discovery: Schema-driven forms in Vue
description:
## Description

We want to create a configuration UI to help setup SAST configuration options https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3262.

This issue is about exploring possible approaches to building a form from a schema.

Using a schema as the single source of truth, the ~frontend can dynamically generate a form with all the necessary fields. This will help to dramatically cut down the amount of necessary if/when possible configuration variables/values change in future. It will also help reduce the amount of work necessary for configuration pages of other scanner types in future.

## Plan

- [x] Evaluate various libraries
  - [x] https://github.com/vuelidate/formvuelatte
    - :thumbsup: Implementation is tiny
    - :thumbsup: Zero dependencies
    - :thumbsdown: `master` is on `v0.2.4`, not much activity in last year
    - :thumbsdown: `next` supports Vue 3 only, but has seen more activity recently
    - :thumbsdown: Lacking documentation about schema structure
    - :thumbsdown: Nested schema structures create nested `<form>` elements
  - [x] https://github.com/vue-generators/vue-form-generator
    - :thumbsdown: Uses JSON Schema for data, but also requires a UI schema, which is just a straight-forward representation of HTML in plain JS (i.e., faux vnodes)
    - :thumbsdown: Large, comes with built-in components (unnecessarily heavy at 41kB gzipped)
    - :thumbsdown: Last activity ~15 months ago
    - :thumbsdown:  Depends on `lodash` and `fecha` internally
  - [x] https://gitlab.com/formschema/native/tree/v1
    - :thumbsup:/:thumbsdown: Uses JSON Schema. :thumbsup: because it's well defined, :thumbsdown: because it's not expressive enough for this feature.
    - :thumbsdown: v1 last activity ~12 months ago
    - :thumbsdown: Too prescriptive about label/component structure
    - :thumbsdown: v2 is in alpha (not for production), thought there is more activity here than in v1
- [x] Evaluate possible custom implementation(s)
    - Good article: https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/Validating-Schema-Driven-forms-with-Vuelidate/
        - Written by the author of formvuelatte
        - Implementation is very similar to formvuelatte, and tiny, and flexible enough for our needs
        - Can implement enhancements as we need them

## Definition of done

- [x] A decision on how to build the form (either a custom implementation, or using an existing library)
    - Use an approach very similar to what's described in https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/Validating-Schema-Driven-forms-with-Vuelidate/

title: [VSA] Remove instance-level Value Stream Analytics
description:
### Problem to solve

With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/196455 we removed access to instance level value stream analytics from the top level navigation in favour of group level VSA. Currently VSA cannot be accessed via the navigation bar, but can be browsed to directly. 

We should eliminate any remaining Instance-level VSA code to correctly reflect this.

### User experience goal

We are moving analytics features to the group level, this will help clear up any possible confusion on how to access VSA. Additionally, the additional code and tests are starting to impact developing new features.

### Proposal
* Remove the route and move the controller code/views to the group level
* Update feature specs and other related tests
* Remove the group selector from the VSA ~frontend code
* Update the VSA ~frontend vuex state to remove code related to selecting a group, since the group details are populated via `data-*` attributes from the ~backend

Question, should we still be able to access VSA at the instance level? Given its not in the navigation

ekigbo  4 days ago
Yeah, its causing me some issues with the filter bar MRs :sweat_smile:, I only noticed it was still accessible because I suddenly had some spec failures.
If we need to keep it for a abit longer ill add some work arounds to fix the specs

we can remove it in 12.2

blabuschagne  4 days ago
Guess we missed our shot then :laughing:

John-Mason Shackelford  4 days ago
@Jeremy I have been under the impression that you are generally in favor of moving away from instance level features toward group level given growth of dot-com and ability to nest groups.

John-Mason Shackelford  4 days ago
Any reason we should keep instance level VSA? (edited) 

John-Mason Shackelford  4 days ago
@ekigbo I suggest moving forward with an approach that breaks instance level VSA and see if we get a complaint given that it is inaccessible from the UI but only directly via a URL. (edited) 

Jeremy  4 days ago
I have been under the impression that you are generally in favor of moving away from instance level features toward group level given growth of dot-com and ability to nest groups.
Yes, I'm in favor of an approach that lets GitLab.com users benefit from these features. I think instance-level features make this difficult, but I'm certainly open to other ideas. The challenge is making sure that we can use a new feature on both self-managed and GitLab.com, and instance-level things have historically been hard to do that with. (edited) 

Dan Jensen  4 days ago
Note: here is our issue to move DevOps Score and Cohorts out of instance level:  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/205909

John-Mason Shackelford  4 days ago
Thanks very much Dan. Really appreciate it.

John-Mason Shackelford  4 days ago

epic.title: [VSA] Refactor project-level feature to use group-level code

title: [Step 3] Update snippet statistics after project import
description:
At the moment, the snippet info inside a project export, can be in three states depending on when the exported file was created:

- No repositories bundles and db data only
- Mix of repositories and db data only
- Only repository bundles

When the snippet doesn't have any repository data, after we import the snippet information, we manually migrate that snippet and perform commits operations to recreate the snippet repository with the existing db information. This means that, at some point, the git operation gets to the `PostReceive` worker. In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223712 we implemented some logic to automatically refresh the snippet and project statistics after a git operation.

This means that, for snippet with no repository bundles, the statistics are updated automatically after recreating the snippet repository.

Nevertheless, when the exported file has snippet bundles, no git operation is performed. Therefore, we need to manually trigger the snippet statistics refresh after the bundle is imported.

title: [Step 3] Update project snippets stat when snippet is deleted.
description:
In the `Snippets::DestroyService`, after the snippet has been successfully removed, we need to call `ProjectCacheWorker.perform_async(snippet.project.id, [], [:snippets_size])` to update the snippet's size stored in the project statistics.

It's important that we only do this for project snippets.

epic.title: Include total snippet repository size in project storage size and namespace statistics

title: [Step 2] Include snippets size into project statistics
description:
We need to include the total snippets repository size in the project `storage_size` column. For that, we need first to sum all project snippets statistics `repository_size` and then include it in the `update_storage_size` method:

```ruby
class ProjectStatistics
  default_value_for :snippets_size, 0

  COLUMNS_TO_REFRESH = [:repository_size, :wiki_size, :lfs_objects_size, :commit_count, :snippets_size].freeze

  def update_snippets_size
    self.snippets_size = project.snippets.with_statistics.sum(:repository_size) # This is some method that sums all snippet repository size
  end

  def update_storage_size
    self.storage_size = repository_size + wiki_size.to_i + lfs_objects_size + build_artifacts_size + packages_size + snippets_size
  end
end

class Snippet
  scope :with_statistics, -> { joins(:statistics) }
end
```

title: [Step 1] Add `snippets_size` column in ProjectStatistics
description:
We're going to include the snippet storage size, within the project total storage size. For that, we need to gather all snippets' repository size, sum them, and store them in this new column.

We don't need to set any default value. We will take care of that in the code.

epic.title: Include total snippet repository size in project storage size and namespace statistics

title: [Step 3] Update snippet stats in PostReceive worker
description:
After a git operation is performed over a snippet, we [expire the project statistics](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/workers/post_receive.rb#L82). Right after, we need to call the `snippet.statistics.refresh!` in order to update all the data we need from the repository.

This will be also the place where we will create the statistics relation if it doesn't exist. Something like:

```ruby
stats = snippet.statistics || snippet.build_statistics
stats.refresh!
```

We also need to update the projects global statistics to include the new value. It has to be after we execute `stats.refresh!`. For this, we need to call `ProjectCacheWorker.perform_async(snippet.project.id, [], [:snippets_size])`. It's important that we only call this worker if the snippet is a project one.

epic.title: Include total snippet repository size in project storage size and namespace statistics

title: [Step 2] Add counting logic to `SnippetStatistics`
description:
Similar to `ProjectStatistics` we need the logic to store the different data we want to retrieve from the snippet repository into the database. We will need something like:

```ruby
alias_method :storage_size, :repository_size

def update_commit_count
  self.commit_count = snippet.repository.commit_count
end

def update_repository_size
  self.repository_size = snippet.repository.size * 1.megabyte
end

def update_file_count
  self.file_count = snippet.repository.ls_files(snippet.repository.root_ref)
end

def refresh!
  update_commit_count
  update_repository_size
  update_file_count

  save!
end
```

epic.title: Include total snippet repository size in project storage size and namespace statistics

title: [Step 1] Add SnippetStatistics table and class
description:
We need to add a new table `snippet_statistics` similar to `project_statistics`. In this table we will store:

- the repository size
- the total number of files in HEAD
- the number of commits

We will also need the new `SnippetStatistics` class with a foreign key to the snippet.

title: Project Bots are counted as licensed users
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

While using the [Project access tokens (Alpha)](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/settings/project_access_tokens.html#project-bot-users)feature, the bots created are consuming the seats and users over license field is incrementing by 1 user for each project access token. 
### Steps to reproduce

- Log in to GitLab.
- Navigate to the project you would like to create an access token for.
- In the Settings menu choose Access Tokens.
- Choose a name and optional expiry date for the token.
- Choose the desired scopes.
- Click the Create project access token button



### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The created bots are consuming the seats and during the renewal the customer has to pay for the extra bots for which they haven't created on their own. 

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Those bots which are being created with the project access tokens shouldn't consume a seat 

We should also update our documentation (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40027) and release post accordingly when this is resolved.

title: Housekeeping and repository cleanup should prune unreferenced LFS objects
description:
## Problem to solve

Using repository cleanup (https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/reducing_the_repo_size_using_git.html#using-the-bfg-repo-cleaner) triggers housekeeping, but `git gc` doesn't prune loose LFS objects. This means the repo size can't be reduced by removing LFS objects.

## Further details

Feature flag: `:cleanup_lfs_during_gc`

## Proposal

* When running repository cleanup, prune LFS objects included in the uploaded commit map.

* Ensure notifications take into account LFS space/storage

title: PARTIAL SUCCESS: Upgrade Geo multi-server installation from 12.9.10 to 12.10.12
description:
### Versions

Current: `12.9.10`
Target: `12.10.12`

### Upgrade checklist

#### Preflight - upgrade

* [x] Create a zoom meeting and schedule a recorded meeting
* [x] Check if the Geo HA update instructions contain [version specific changes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/updating_the_geo_nodes.html#version-specific-update-steps)
* [x] Check if PostgreSQL is already the latest shipped version. If not, ensure PostgreSQL upgrade instructions are followed.
* [x] Check if any [upgrade warnings exist](https://docs.gitlab.com/omnibus/update/#version-specific-changes)
* [x] Verify that the Geo cluster is healthy pre-upgrade.  For a no-downtime upgrade, remove deploy nodes from load balancers/stop sidekiq and run looping-pipeline to confirm test pass.
* [x] Find the [latest packaged version](https://packages.gitlab.com/gitlab/gitlab-ee) of GitLab that [can be used for zero downtime upgrades](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/update/README.html#upgrading-without-downtime )
* [x] Set up the [looping test pipeline](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/looping-pipeline) to run during the upgrade procedure.


### Upgrade

* [x] Retrieve a beverage of choice within a drinkable temperature range
* [x] Join Zoom meeting and wait for arrival. Hit the **record** button
* [x] Manually trigger the looping test pipeline to start running smoke tests before upgrading the primary site and before upgrading the secondary site (if failures happen during the primary site update)
* [x] Perform upgrade steps described in [latest documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/omnibus/update/README.html#multi-node--ha-deployment-with-geo).  
* [x] During the upgrade process, monitor the looping test pipeline for any failures
* [x] Record any issues encountered during the upgrade
* [x] Verify cluster health post upgrade
* [x] Verify PostgreSQL version is correct

### Postflight

* [x] Record the upgrade outcome as SUCCESS (upgrade with zero downtime), FAILED, PARTIAL SUCCESS (upgrade but with downtime or unconfirmed downtime)
* [x] Open new issues and inform @nhxnguyen and @fzimmer to confirm next steps
* [x] Create new issue for the next upgrade demo (the next versions) and assign to @nhxnguyen and @fzimmer 
* [x] Open an issue/MR to update Geo validation tests docs page (doc/administration/geo/replication/geo_validation_tests.md)

title: Update Composition Analysis Analyzers to Go 1.14
description:
## Description

[Go 1.14](https://golang.org/doc/go1.14) was [released](https://blog.golang.org/go1.14) 25 February 2020. We should update our tools to use the latest stable version of Go.

As of today, [klar](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar) and [gemnasium-maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) already use Go 1.14. This discrepancy exists because they both have a multi-stage Dockerfile, and don't rely on the [shared CI config](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml) to build the analyzer CLI.

## Proposal

Update Analyzers maintained by @gitlab-org/secure/composition-analysis-be to use Go 1.14, and leverage the [shared CI config](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml) so that all analyzers are compiled with the same version of Go, including the projects that have a multi-stage Dockerfile.

There's no need to release a new version since this is not a security fix and there's no behavior change.

## Implementation plan

- [x] update the [shared CI config](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml) to introduce `GO_VERSION`, pass it as a Docker build argument, and upgrade to Go 1.14 https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/135
- Upgrade projects having a multi-stage Dockerfile to use `GO_VERSION` (build argument), ~~and release new versions~~
  - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/merge_requests/57
  - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/60
- Check the other projects, ~~and release new versions~~
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js

title: Move pipeline header to GraphQL
description:
## Summary

As part of [the effort to move our API to GraphQL](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/#vision), we need to move the Pipeline Header to use GraphQL instead of the current service architecture.

The Pipeline Header refers to the header on the pipeline details page (see screenshot below for example)

![Screen_Shot_2020-06-19_at_1.21.05_PM](/uploads/50bc979f9cca5cb1449371bb8a5c73d5/Screen_Shot_2020-06-19_at_1.21.05_PM.png)

The frontend would need access to some data that is currently unavailable:

Query:
The user
```
{ 
  pipeline(id){
    user{
       ...fields of the user that triggered the pipeline
    }
}
```

Fields we are currently using:
```
name
path
email
avatar_url
userAvatarAltText
status_tooltip_html
```

Mutations:
- Retry pipeline by ID
- Cancel pipeline by ID
- Delete pipeline by ID

By looking at the pattern of other similar mutations, it seems the mutation returns back a field that takes an ID in which the errors are. Example of what the FE query would look like:

```
mutation cancelPipeline($id: ID) {
  cancelPipeline(input: { $id: ID }) {
    errors
  }
}

```

## Improvements

This allows us to move away from an outdated file structure, and move onto a more maintainable solution.

## Risks

There may be parts of the pipeline GraphQL schema that are needed by the header that are not included yet. We will need to do some client-side GraphQL queries in the meantime to make the transition easier.

## Involved components

[/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/components/header_component.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6e76c9598ccbbdab9dd81891e20423fe69f834e2/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/components/header_component.vue)

title: Partitioning: UI/UX Changes needed to encourage optimal querying of partitioned audit_events
description:
From https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3206#note_355626946 it has been identified that there will need to be some UI/UX changes to the audit events page to align with the partitioning schema.

Segmented control design suggestion here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223260#note_376058968

Design Discussions here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223260#note_375583480

Proposal
---
As an instance admin, I want the ability to switch between 3 shortcut options (last 7 days, last 14 days, this month) in addition to the existing custom date range picker, so that I can quickly filter down results. 


**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Given that I am an Administrator, when I navigate to Monitoring > Audit Log, then I should see `This month` selected by default with the dates pre-defined in the date picker
- When I pick either of the segmented control options, then the date picker should change the dates to match
- When I am picking a custom date within the date picker, then I can only pick a max range of 31 days
- When I am picking a custom date within the date picker, then I cannot pick a date in future


|[Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/hyGQ9Yittp4B7NezIRuONc/223260-Querying-of-partitioned-audit_events?node-id=1%3A2)|
|---|
|![Segmented_control_with_custom_date_picker](/uploads/4dbe7182ea62bfdf0f8ac7816e771f02/Segmented_control_with_custom_date_picker.gif)|

### Implementation Outline

~frontend - `2`

1. Update the `<audit-events-filter>` layout (the mobile view should also be looked at)
1. Apply the default end date (today) if no if no end date is set
1. Apply the default start date (1 month) if no start date is set
1. Add the date range buttons to `<date-range-field>` and set new date range `value` on click
1. Update `<date-range-field>` to only allow a max date range of 31 days and no future dates

### Milestone Goal
- [x] `13.4` complete ~"workflow::planning breakdown"

title: Separate Pipelines Detail Bundle File
description:
## Summary

The [app/assets/javascripts/pipelines](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines) directory has a few different Vue applications in it.

The [pipeline_details_bundle.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6e76c9598ccbbdab9dd81891e20423fe69f834e2/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/pipeline_details_bundle.js) contains the code to initialize all of the Vue applications. Often these initializations include code that only that specific app cares about.

We should split these initialize functions into their own files so that we can isolate these apps into their own codebases.

## Improvements

We are [migrating the apps in this directory to use GraphQL (see epic)](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3640). In order to do this, we need to ensure that each app is isolated before we can start migrating them each to GraphQL. This will also help us work on migrations in parallel.

Another benefit is that we have cleaner, easier to follow, and more maintainable file structures inside of this directory.

This also ensures that we don't load extra unnecessary javascript code onto pages that don't need it.

## Risks

Because these apps all use this same bundle file and mediator, it will be difficult to break them apart. There is a risk that we break some functionality in the process, but our spec tests will ensure that we don't merge breaking functionality into master.

## Involved components

- [app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/pipeline_details_bundle.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6e76c9598ccbbdab9dd81891e20423fe69f834e2/app/assets/javascripts/pipelines/pipeline_details_bundle.js)

title: Refactor test report summary response to contain "totals"
description:
## Overview

Right now the test report summary json response contains several top level nodes that represent totals. It would be cleaner in the code and response if there were a single top-level "total" node, as well as the top level "test_suites" node.

## Proposal

Refactor `lib/gitlab/ci/reports/test_report_summary.rb` and the frontend that consumes it so that the response instead looks something like:  

```json
{
  "total": {
    "time": "x",
    "count": "x",
    "success": "x",
    "failed": "x",
    "errored": "x",
    "skipped": "x"
  }
  "test_suites": ...
}
```

Something to note is we will not be able to reuse existing entities as we would need to create new ones after performing this refactor.


## Original Description
<details>
The following discussion from !33431 should be addressed:

#### From @ayufan [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33431#note_361363495):  (+5 comments):

Do we need that? Can we just render `total`?

#### From @morefice:

What did you have in mind? Something like this?

```json
{
  "total": {
    "time": "x",
    "count": "x",
    "success": "x",
    "failed": "x",
    "errored": "x",
    "skipped": "x"
  }
  "test_suites": ...
}
```

This implies a couple of things we need to keep in mind:

1. We will not be able to reuse existing entities as we would need to create new ones
1. We would need to tweak the ~frontend with this new API

#### From @ayufan:

Yes, this would be preferred. For ~frontend the usage of `total:` should be a very minimal change. Can you try to do it in next MR and fix ~frontend @morefice so we would not have to create new ones.

</details>

title: Remove trufflehog dependency in the secrets analyzer
description:
## Summary
The secrets analyzer uses both Trufflehog and Gitleaks. Both of these scanners do the same thing in the context of the current implementation -- they do simple regex checks on rules defined by us. However as we build out features for the secrets analyzer (rule packs, customization, historic source code extraction, etc) we will need a scanner that supports these features. Gitleaks supports these features and more.

Additionally, removing a scanner will simplify the code base and reduce future tech debt. 

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

## Improvements
- smaller secrets image size (no trufflehog dependency)
- faster scans (no double scanning with two different scanners)
- simplified and reduced codebase
- committing to a scanner that is actively maintained
- Trufflehog does not offer commit scan ranges which will be needed for `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/36860`

<!--
Explain the benefits of refactoring this code.
See also https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/values/index.html#say-why-not-just-what
-->

## Risks

<!--
Please list features that can break because of this refactoring and how you intend to solve that.
-->
We will need to verify that the gitleaks scanner is picking up the same secrets as the trufflehog scanner. 

## Involved components
- [ ] Removal of the [trufflehog package](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/tree/master/scanner/trufflehog)
- [ ] Removal of trufflehog install [the dockerfile](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/master/Dockerfile#L17)
- [ ] Migrate [trufflehog specific rules](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets/-/blob/master/scanner/trufflehog/rule.go) to gitleaks
- [ ] Updated trufflehog reference [in the docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/secret_detection/#configuration)
<!--
List files or directories that will be changed by the refactoring.
-->

description:

title: Remove vuex files which are no longer available since the SAV feature flag has been removed completely
description:
## Summary

The [SAV feature flag has been completely removed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33488). This means now we can start removing the security dashboard components and vuex files.

## More information

Previously, we had an old security dashboard and a new security dashboard. If the SAV feature flag was enabled, the new security dashboard would be shown; otherwise, the old security dashboard would be shown. Now that the feature flag has been removed, only the new security dashboard is used, and the old security dashboard is now dead code that needs to be removed.

Additionally, many Vuex modules are loaded and unused in [first_class_init](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/ac7226824f2d6ce51d675ceccbdebff0de8c4f2d/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/first_class_init.js#L64), so this ticket should house the work to evaluate which modules, if any, should still be loaded.

Finally, there are some non-Vuex files referencing Vuex files (i.e. `ee/security_dashboard/store/constants` and potentially some `utils.js`/`constants.js` files in `ee/security_dashboard/store/modules/*/utils.js`/`ee/security_dashboard/store/modules/*/constants.js`

![image](/uploads/20d0a94317b82ca64188436c6fd2c33c/image.png)

so these files should potentially be moved out of the `/store` directory

It's highly recommended to manually assign the MR to @svedova because he implemented most of the new security dashboard and would have a good idea of which files are still used or not.

## Improvements

- Removes code that's no longer used.

## Risks

Some of the vuex files are still used by the new security dashboards. We need to make sure that whatever we remove it's not used. The security tab on a pipeline job also uses some of the components, so please double-check there as well:

||
|-|
|![ksnip_20200622-231724](/uploads/9f6dc315151fc20975d2c4f79744f410/ksnip_20200622-231724.png)|

## Involved components

Many files that are backed by Vuex under: `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components`

Many files in the store: `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/store`

title: Extract instance level empty state to a separate component
description:
## Summary

Currently the `first_class_instance_security_dashboard`'s `<template>` section is `67` lines long. `1/3` of it is the empty state. Together with the `if`/`else` statements it makes it hard to read the code. If we can extract that bit into a separate component it can reduce the file size and make it easier to read through the code. 

## Risks

I don't see any risk involved in this.

## Involved components

`ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/first_class_instance_security_dashboard.vue`

## Optional: Intended side effects

There shouldn't be any side effect.

## Implementation plan

- [ ] Cut the `<gl-empty-state>` component and it's content and create a new component from it.
- [ ] Update tests accordingly
- [x] No need for documentation as this is not a user facing refactoring

title: Enclose `release-cli` steps in an array
description:
### Summary When integration testing the Rails - Runner - Releaser CLI integration, it was found that the `multi_build_steps` feature was correctly producing the `releaser-cli` script, but not enclosing the `script` contents in an array, which is the required interface for the Runner. This problem and the solution has been described [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-runner/-/issues/26307#note_364134670). Specifically `:script` should be sending an array, ie: instead of: ```ruby { "name" => "release", "script" => "release-cli create --ref \"$CI_COMMIT_SHA\" --name \"Release $CI_COMMIT_SHA\" --tag-name \"release-$CI_COMMIT_SHA\" --description \"Created using the release-cli $EXTRA_DESCRIPTION\"", "timeout" => 3600, "when" => "on_success", "allow_failure" => false } ``` It should be: ```ruby { "name" => "release", "script" => ["release-cli create --ref \"$CI_COMMIT_SHA\" --name \"Release $CI_COMMIT_SHA\" --tag-name \"release-$CI_COMMIT_SHA\" --description \"Created using the release-cli $EXTRA_DESCRIPTION\""], "timeout" => 3600, "when" => "on_success", "allow_failure" => false } ``` ### Steps to reproduce A full end-to-end test can only be done manually. The steps to do this are described [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-runner/-/issues/26307#note_364134670). ### Example Project (If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report) (If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? (What actually happens) ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? (What you should see instead) ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots (Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.) ### Output of checks (If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com) #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes (If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)

title: Remove stale merge request refs
description:
## Problem to solve

Every merge request created results in up to two new `refs/merge-requests` (`refs/merge-requests/<id>/head` and `refs/merge-request/<id>/merge`) being created, and these appear to never be deleted. This results in all these refs being transferred in every push. Even a tiny 1 line change must transfer all this data, making Git very slow.

For example:

- `www-gitlab-com` has 285,000 refs, of which 28% are `refs/merge-requests`
  - total refs transferred is 25MB uncompressed, and 7MB compressed.
- `gitlab` has 108,000 refs, of which 46% are `ref/merge-requests`
  - total refs transferred is 9.3MB uncompressed, and 2.8MB compressed.

## Further details

## Proposal

Merge request refs should be expired when they have been merged or closed for more than 14 days.

These does not mean the data will be deleted. A `refs/keep-around` can be created. These are hidden, and therefore excluded from ref advertisement. They will not be referenced on push/pull and should therefore improve performance.

epic.title: 💪 Merge Request performance improvements

## Overview

We recently had a [security incident](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-security/secops/operations/-/issues/933) involving one of our [demo applications](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/defend/demos) deployed in the [demo cluster](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/defend/demos/cluster-management).

## Problem to solve

The demo applications:

1. Are used frequently and they need to be available. 
1. Cannot be used to gain access to our GCP account or resources.
1. Must showcase Defend's Container Security features.

## Tasks

- [ ] Review existing applications.
- [ ] Confirm which ones are still needed.
- [ ] Suggest any suitable replacements.
- [ ] Suggest other security measures to harden the environment.

title: Add `ref`, `milestones` and `released_at` to releaser-cli and yml
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Currently there are some decrepencies between the `:release` yaml, the capabilities of the [REST API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/#create-a-release) and the `releaser-cli`, when creating a release. 

| REST API | release yaml | releaser-cli |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| `ref` | No | Yes |
| `milestones` | No | No |
| `released_at` | No | No |

Please note, this issue does not address release assets or binary assets, as they are being separately handled.

The `:release` yaml needs to have these items added:

- `ref`
- `milestones`
- `released_at`

The `releaser-cli` needs to have these item added, and this is covered [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/release-cli/-/issues/43):

- `milestones`
- `released_at`

No Runner changes will be needed to complete this issue.

Example yaml with the additional nodes:

```yaml
release_job:
  stage: 'release'
  only: 'tags'
  script:
    - echo 'running release_job'
  release:
     name: 'Release $CI_COMMIT_SHA'
     description: 'Created using the release-cli $EXTRA_DESCRIPTION'
     tag_name: 'release-$CI_COMMIT_SHA'
     ref: '$CI_COMMIT_SHA'
     milestones: 
       - 'm1'
       - 'm2'
       - 'm3'
     released_at: '2020-07-15T08:00:00Z'
```

Example script for the `releaser-cli`:

```sh
release-cli create --name "Release $CI_COMMIT_SHA" --description "Created using the release-cli $EXTRA_DESCRIPTION" --tag-name "release-$CI_COMMIT_SHA" --ref "$CI_COMMIT_SHA" --released-at "2020-07-15T08:00:00Z" --milestone "m1" --milestone "m2" --milestone "m3"
```

Each time I see one I think "oh, my last push failed", and I run to my laptop only to find it's a successful pipeline.

This is a screenshot of what the email preview looks like on iOS. The majority of the text is identical except for one word at the end, which makes it hard to identify at a glance.

I've learnt to be alarmed by the failure emails, and these look too alike.
>>>

title: Geo: Fix incorrect Package File progress bar total count
description:
### Summary ![image](/uploads/56df270896e017c7671f50c85dc582a0/image.png) The failures are a separate issue (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223094). This issue is about the "Queued: 75" part. The "Total: 122" is based on the number of Package Files on the primary. Since selective sync is on, this discrepancy cannot resolve by itself. Instead, the total needs to equal the registry count. ### Steps to reproduce (How one can reproduce the issue - this is very important) ### Example Project (If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report) (If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? (What actually happens) ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? (What you should see instead) ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots (Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.) ### Output of checks (If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com) #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes (If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)

title: Geo: Package File Registries are not being excluded when using object storage, and "Allow object storage sync" is disabled
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

### Summary

The registry records of object stored package files should not be created when "Allow object storage sync" is disabled.

### Steps to reproduce

(How one can reproduce the issue - this is very important)

### Example Project

(If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report)

(If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version)

All object stored package files are attempted to be downloaded, and all fail with this in `geo.log`:

```
{"severity":"INFO","time":"2020-06-18T14:52:44.702Z","correlation_id":"02e378e64bacce1847b5a0a113553399","class":"Geo::BlobDownloadService","host":"geo.staging.gitlab.com","message":"Blob download","job_id":"218392160d5ee1907aa33327","mark_as_synced":false,"download_success":false,"bytes_downloaded":0,"primary_missing_file":false,"download_time_s":0.02,"reason":"Skipping transfer as this secondary node is not allowed to replicate content on Object Storage"}
```

logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.)

### Output of checks

(If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com)

### Possible fixes

This method or its caller need to be scoped to locally stored files if "Allow object storage sync" is disabled: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/packages/package_file.rb#L43

Similar to: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/finders/geo/attachment_registry_finder.rb#L158

title: Improve diff tree list performance
description:
At the moment we always created and mount the diff tree list component even if the component is hidden by the user https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/559c62f76716ec7338e4abc42214e2ea06655f3b/app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/app.vue#L401 

For large diffs, this means we creating a lot of components that may never get shown to the user because they might never toggle the tree list or if the tree list gets hidden automatically by the size of the screen (mobile for example)

Few options to fix this:

1. Maybe keep as is and optimize some child components (though maybe we should optimize as well)
1. Change to a `v-if`. We get the best performance on initial render as its not going anything, but we may see some slow down when the user toggles the tree view.
1. Change to use the Vue virtual scroll list that we have available. This is probably fine UX wise as we have the search bar and also `cmd+f` (or windows equivalent) will work for the diff files themselves.

We could also combine 1 & 2 and go for the best performance gain possible :stuck_out_tongue: 

/cc @andr3

title: Display a default list when adding environments to feature flag strategies
description:
### Problem to solve

When adding environments to a strategy of a feature flag we display a searchable dropdown that allows a user to find and select environments to add to a strategy.  We are not currently prepopulating a list so users have to first search before a list is displayed.  

| Screenshot   |
| --- |
| ![Screenshot_2020-08-11_at_22.04.53](/uploads/03969680a4c0c87cd040628ff49118a6/Screenshot_2020-08-11_at_22.04.53.gif) |

### Intended users

Feature flag managers

### User experience goal
By providing a default we can potentially avoid an extra step in the creation process.

### Proposal

Preloading environments on opening the dropdown

### Permissions and Security

Users can only modify strategies that include environments they have access to. Users should only be allowed to add/remove environments they have access to.

### Documentation

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Improved user experience when creating/modifying feature flags.

### Links / references

[MR Breakdown Plan](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223084#note_389174807)

title: Disable commenting on symlinks in an MR
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

In the context of pursuing a solution for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33867 we realise that will involve significant overhaul of internal mechanisms that require better and deeper planning. 

For the time being, it has been proposed to simply disable the commenting on these cases, to avoid breaking the experience or loss of data:

@pedroms wrote:

> We would need to disable the comment icon button and display a tooltip explaining why it's disabled to set the right expectations for users. Maybe something like so:
> 
> ![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/create-stage/uploads/de094d181aa639599dc0c13d9d7e38ed/image.png)
> 
> This tooltip text could be used for both added and deleted symbolic links. For files that replace or are replaced by symbolic links, we could use this tooltip text: `Commenting on files that replace or are replaced by symbolic links is currently not supported.`

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Avoid sending users down a flow that will result in error or data loss.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Disable comments whenever the diff file is a symlink and cannot, at this time, receive a comment.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/create-stage/-/issues/12670#note_361521691 

Deeper refactor of the Diffs app is in discussion but not yet able to be picked up.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

title: Unauthorized read for conan repository
description:
**[HackerOne report #901473](https://hackerone.com/reports/901473)** by `fushbey` on 2020-06-18, assigned to @jeremymatos:

### Summary  
Hi, I want to report an unauthorized read related to conan packages, I was not quite familiar with Conan so I had doubts but after several trying, I am confident the bug is there, please confirm to me if I am right.  
The bug is, a user that is Guest in a private group, can list Conan packages available in the registry despite not having enough access level, indeed the web restricts access:  
- When accessing the Web page for the group > Packages & Registries . Surprisingly this menu item is shown, however on clicking on it the page shows an error message: `Something went wrong while fetching the packages list. `, Inspecting the network calls we see indeed we got a 403 response. to `/api/v4/groups/6/packages?page=1&per_page=20&sort=desc&order_by=created_at&package_name=`. I come back to this API call later.  
-When accessing the Web page for our project The menu item "Packages & repositories" is not even shown, accessing it directly with the URL returns a 404.

However, using `conan search` does return results.

### Steps to reproduce  
I am gonna assume you installed conan successfully (which by the way did not install very easily on my Gitlab EE container)  
1 - userA creates a private group: cpp-group  
1 - userA creates a private project in that group: cpp-hello  
1 - userA invites userB as guest  
1 - userA: Create a Conan package as explained [here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/conan_repository/index.html)  
    * `conan new Hello/1.0 -t`  
    * `conan create . cpp-group+cpp-hello/beta`  
2 - userA: Add our Conan registry to remote:  
`conan remote add gitlab https://gitlab.example.com/api/v4/packages/conan`  
3 - Upload the package with the owner of the private group

```  
CONAN_LOGIN_USERNAME=userA CONAN_PASSWORD=<userA PAT> conan upload Hello/0.1@cpp-group+cpp-hello/beta --all  
```  
4 - Search for Hello package using userA

```  
CONAN_LOGIN_USERNAME=userA CONAN_PASSWORD=<userA PAT> conan search Hello* -r gitlab

Existing package recipes:

Hello/1.0@cpp-group+cpp-hello/beta

```

5 - Delete userA from cache, make sure it worked:  
```  
conan user && conan user --clean && conan user  
```  
6 - search for packages using userB  
```  
CONAN_LOGIN_USERNAME=userB CONAN_PASSWORD=<userB PAT> conan search Hello* -r gitlab

Existing package recipes:

Hello/1.0@cpp-group+cpp-hello/beta  
```

7 - Compare that with the API call:  
```  
curl -s -H 'Authorization: Bearer <userB'sPAT>' 'http://gitlab.example.com/api/v4/groups/<PROJECT_ID>/packages?page=1&per_page=20&sort=desc&order_by=created_at&package_name=' | jq  
{
  "message": "403 Forbidden"  
}

```

To prove myself there is a bug and not some caching problem I tested outside the container with userB and still worked.

### Impact

The user can list recipes from a private Conan registry although the Web does not show them.


### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Allowing unauthorized users to know the packages used in a repository with a private Conan registry.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Same as the Web UI (and API), return a forbidden response instead of showing the package name.

## Impact

Read above.

title: Hide scanners that aren't run from pipelines' security report summaries
description:
This follows up on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222374

## Problem to solve

We currently use the `securityReportSummary` GraphQL endpoint to fetch the count of vulnerabilities found for each scanners in pipelines' Security report. If a particular scanner did not run, the endpoint isn't "aware" of it and reports 0 vulnerabilities regardless.

## Proposal

Adjust the GraphQL endpoint to return `nil` for scanners that did not run, and handle this properly in the ~frontend to not render the corresponding lines in the summary.

## Implementation plan

~backend
- [x] Respond with `nil` for queried scanners that aren't setup yet

~frontend (could most likely be done in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222374)
- [x] Handle the case where some lines in the report are empty (`null`) and abort their rendering: this was handled in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35060

/cc @craigmsmith @cam.x

title: 500 error while sorting MRs with `milestone due date` criteria on MR user dashboard
description:
# Summary

While trying to run a filter on MRs in dashboard page with `Approved By` as one of the filter criteria, page runs into `500` error. Sentry log of the same is attached below.

### Steps to reproduce.

- Go to your MR dashboard on https://gitlab.com/dashboard/merge_requests
- Go to `Merged` tab.
- Add filter `Approved By` with any user selection, by default this can potentially try to load a lot of matches so you can additionally add `Milestone` as one more criteria.
- Sort by `Milestone Due Date`
- Hit <kbd>Enter</kbd>/<kbd>Return</kbd> to apply the filter.

Page runs into `500` error instead of loading the matching MRs.

# Sentry Details

https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/1670818/?referrer=gitlab_plugin

```
PG::GroupingError: ERROR:  column "milestones.due_date" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function
LINE 1: ...uests"."id" HAVING (COUNT(users.id) = 1) ORDER BY milestones...
                                                             ^

  active_record/connection_adapters/postgresql_adapter.rb:675:in `exec_params'
    @connection.exec_params(sql, type_casted_binds)
  active_record/connection_adapters/postgresql_adapter.rb:675:in `block (2 levels) in exec_no_cache'
    @connection.exec_params(sql, type_casted_binds)
  active_support/dependencies/interlock.rb:48:in `block in permit_concurrent_loads'
    yield
  active_support/concurrency/share_lock.rb:187:in `yield_shares'
    yield
  active_support/dependencies/interlock.rb:47:in `permit_concurrent_loads'
    @lock.yield_shares(compatible: [:load]) do
...
(175 additional frame(s) were not displayed)

ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: PG::GroupingError: ERROR:  column "milestones.due_date" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function
LINE 1: ...uests"."id" HAVING (COUNT(users.id) = 1) ORDER BY milestones...
                                                             ^

ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: PG::GroupingError: ERROR:  column "milestones.due_date" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function
LINE 1: ...uests"."id" HAVING (COUNT(users.id) = 1) ORDER BY milestones...
                                                             ^

```

## :tools: Workarounds

### Change the sort order

Change the sort order to something other than **Milestone due date**.

See [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223062#note_1027267226) for more info. 

- `200`: [https://gitlab.com/dashboard/merge\_requests?approved\_by\_usernames%5B%5D=bcarranza&scope=all&sort=priority&state=opened](https://gitlab.com/dashboard/merge_requests?approved_by_usernames%5B%5D=bcarranza&scope=all&sort=priority&state=opened)
- `500`: [https://gitlab.com/dashboard/merge\_requests?approved\_by\_usernames%5B%5D=bcarranza&scope=all&sort=milestone&state=opened](https://gitlab.com/dashboard/merge_requests?approved_by_usernames%5B%5D=bcarranza&scope=all&sort=milestone&state=opened)


### Use the API

From [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223062#note_1011768528), the following workaround works in some environments:

> Use the [Merge Request API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/merge_requests.html) with the `approved_by_ids` filter.

```
https://gitlab.example.com/api/v4/merge_requests?scope=all&state=opened&approved_by_ids[]=12345
```

title: Re-name project delete "adjourned" and "soft deleted" as "delayed" in docs
description:
### Problem to solve

Delayed project deletion was introduced under https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935 under the name "soft delete".  Technically it is not soft delete, because that would mean the record is permanently hidden from users (not temporarily in a different state).  Internally, the delay was referred to as "adjourned" or "adjournment", which is a term that many users and developers may not understand.

### Proposal

In the docs:

- Refer to "soft delete" as "delayed delete".
- Refer to "adjourned" as "delayed".
- Refer to "adjournment period" as "delay".

### Out of scope

The same changes will be made to the code under https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339478

epic.title: Improvements to delayed project deletion

title: Definition of a high-traffic table for  ‘with_lock_retries’
description:
Should we have a standard definition what a high-traffic table is?

- https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/migration_style_guide.html#when-to-use-the-helper-method

# Solution proposal

Use the below table to find 3 monthly average of updates to that table

```
select avg(count) from 
(select date_trunc('month', updated_at),
      count(*) as count
from users
where updated_at > '2020-03-01'
  AND updated_at < '2020-06-01'
group by 1) monthly_counts;
```

title: Replace angle icons with chevron

After the remapping is complete in the product, then the SVGs can be removed from the [SVG library](http://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-svgs/?q=angle).

| ![angle-right.svg](/uploads/42e4fbc4c5f461d0cbc8ffcb006f337d/angle-right.svg) | `angle-right` | `chevron-lg-right` |
| ![angle-up.svg](/uploads/97064d14271269d3e4826958e6b36026/angle-up.svg) | `angle-up` | `chevron-lg-up` |

title: Update Design of the Container Registry Cleanup Policy for tags
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

The Container Registry contains a multitude of image tags. For many users, there are a lot of stale tags inside the registry that have no value.  We have created the *Cleanup policy for tags* feature to help remove the stale data to control storage costs related to the container registry.

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
-->

### User experience goal

Review the Cleanup policy UI and propose any possible design changes, including field names, text includes, etc to help refine the experience and better enable users.

Another important aspect of this work is to better align the form itself with [Gitlab's Pajamas Guidelines around Forms](https://design.gitlab.com/components/forms).


### Proposal

Create an updated design for the Cleanup Policies based on feedback.

| Current Iteration of the Design |
|---|
|![Settings_Page_small_regex](/uploads/bd772e32af9a66de63c5ae1ed1396961/Settings_Page_small_regex.png)|

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Future iterations
* Near the "cleanup runs every x days" field, include a way for the user to select the start date (i.e. do it tomorrow, then every 7 days)
* Add the ability to run the cleanup policy manually (right now)
* Add a preview ability to get a list of image tags that would be removed if the policy was set to run as is

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->

### Documentation

The design changes should be purely superficial. The core functionality remains the same, but the documentation may need to be updated if field names change.

### Availability & Testing

title: GitLab errors when searching `"logo-text"` in the "Issues" scope of the gitlab-org/gitlab-foss project's search page
description:
### Summary

GitLab errors when searching `"logo-text"` in the Issues scope of the gitlab-org/gitlab-foss project's search page

### Steps to reproduce

1. Browse https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss
2. Key-in `"logo-text"` in the upper-right search textbox in the navigation bar
3. Click the :mag: icon to make the search query
4. In the /search page, click the "Issues" scope

Also the https://gitlab.com/search?group_id=9970&project_id=13083&repository_ref=master&scope=issues&search=%22logo-text%22&snippets=false URL should also trigger the issue.

### Example Project

Reproducible at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss as of 2020/6/17 16:40

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

500 error page appears

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Search result displayed without error

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![gitlab search '"logo-text"' bug reproduction clip](/uploads/92131addcf7f8deb743c58f874894a44/gitlab_search___logo-text___bug_reproduction_clip.gif)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

#### Results of GitLab environment info

This bug happens on GitLab.com

#### Results of GitLab application Check

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

Possibly a duplicate of #33040 , but not sure.

title: Run migration tests in rspec foss-impact
description:
Run migration tests in rspec foss-impact

```shell
rspec_matched_tests tmp/matching_foss_tests.txt "--tag ~quarantine --tag ~geo"
```

instead of 

```shell
rspec_matched_tests tmp/matching_foss_tests.txt "--tag ~quarantine --tag ~geo --tag ~level:migration"
```

This would stop https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/222796 from being merged.

title: Refactor DAST Python modules
description:
# The Problem

DAST's Python code lives in `src/`. When the `dast` image is built, the files from `src/` are copied into `/zap`, which does not preserve the `src` module. This prevents us from internally accessing our files using `src.`

This creates module conflicts in the unit tests. It also prevents the use of relative imports (`from . import X`, `from .. import Y`)

For example, if there is a class that uses the `report` submodule:

```
# src/custom_hooks.py

import report

class CustomHooks:
    ...
```

and the `report` submodule is tested in `test/unit/report/`, then the test will try to load the `report` module from the tests and fail when it can't find whatever `CustomHooks` is accessing from `src/report`.

This can be see in practice here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast/-/merge_requests/187#note_361639891

# Proposed Solution

1. Move all of the Python except `zap-scan-launcher.py` into a new `src/dast` directory (and module).
2. Pass the original ZAP main scripts into the scan wrapper classes in `zap-scan-launcher.py` (instead of when the scan wrappers are initialized)
3. Internally and in tests, access modules through the `dast` module (or relative imports where appropriate)

title: UpdateRepositoryStorageService should clean up after itself upon encountering a failure
description:
### Problem to solve

As a GitLab admin, I want to have the subject of a `ReplicateRepository` GRPC method invocation failure cleaned up, so that I can re-attempt without having to manually delete the failed replica repository directory from its gitaly storage shard file system by hand.

As I have [learned](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitaly/-/issues/2691) Gitaly is not the appropriate place for such an implementation, but rather the `UpdateRepositoryStorageService` should be responsible for cleaning up after a failure detected from the invocation of the `ReplicateRepository` GRPC method, here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/services/projects/update_repository_storage_service.rb#L84

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

The problem solved here is that when a failure occurs, the failed replica repository is left behind on the destination storage shard file system, and no further attempts may be made, since the repository directory will already exist on the file system of the destination gitaly shard.  This causes a situation in which, at best, gitaly will attempt to set up a second remote configuration and fetch from it into the already existing repository, and at worst, an admin user may give up on the replication or assume it has been successful, and the failed replica repository will continue to exist dormant and unusable on the destination gitaly shard file system indefinitely.

### Intended users

A user with the Sidney persona will use this feature.

### User experience goal

The user should be able to perform a repository replication (move/migration) to another shard without fear that the replica repository will be left in a broken or inconsistent state.

### Proposal

Detect all failures from the invocation of the `Repository#replicate` method, and delete all artifacts created in association with the Service-level procedure on the destination gitaly shard file system.

This clean-up action presents zero risk of customer data loss, since the original repository is never modified (only read) during the replication procedure.

### Further details

Here is [an example failure from which clean-up was required](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2246#note_362413613).

### Permissions and Security

Permissions required are those that are currently required, an administrator-level access API token.

### Documentation

Here is the [current documentation of manual clean-up procedures](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/runbooks/-/blob/master/docs/gitaly/storage-rebalancing.md#finally-failed-replica-repository-deletion).

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

TBD

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Success looks like having no git repository at the `/var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories/$disk_path.git` path on the file system of the destination gitaly shard when there is any failure encountered by the `UpdateRepositoryStorageService` procedure.

### What is the type of buyer?

All buyers/applicability uncertain.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Uncertain/possibly Gitaly.

### Links / references

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitaly/-/issues/2691
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2246#note_362413613
